title: Meet the guy behind @ColIegeStudent, your favorite Twitter account
text:
Meet the guy behind @ColIegeStudent, your favorite Twitter account By Susannah Hutcheson 10:17 am EST January 26, 2017 444 shares EMAIL Andy Rexford, AKA @ColIegeStudent. (Provided by Andy Rexford) 
Four years ago, Andy Rexford sat in his dorm room at Saginaw Valley State University in Michigan and created @ColIegeStudent . Now, with over a million followers and thousands of hilarious tweets, it’s rare that you can take a scroll down your timeline without seeing a @CollegeStudent tweet. Whether talking about the realities of finals week or the necessity of a good ole’ Netflix binge, there’s nothing more relatable. "Attendance is not mandatory" pic.twitter.com/7hYLfFer1d 
— College Student (@ColIegeStudent) January 11, 2017 
When Rexford was a freshman at SVSU, he was a typical college student, enjoying college life and all that came with it. But he felt like something was missing. 
“I saw that there weren’t any popular places to look at funny and relatable things for college, so I created one,” Rexford told USA TODAY College. "Your homework is worth 5% of your grade"… Nice, no homework. 
— College Student (@ColIegeStudent) February 19, 2013 
“I tweeted funny memes and it blew up overnight — and from there, it took off.” 
Overnight, Rexford’s account gained 16,000 followers. A month later, it was at 50,000. Four years later, the account has hit one million. As you can imagine, it’s a lot to keep up with. me: has 3 essays to write 
buzzfeed: we can tell how lonely you are by your choice in bread 
— College Student (@ColIegeStudent) December 15, 2016 
“I’m always using my phone,” he said. “I’m always either on Twitter, Instagram, Tumblr, Reddit or Yik Yak. At nighttime I’ll kind of go over popular stuff for the day, see if there’s any new trends, and schedule posts after that.” Sorority girls pose exactly like meerkats in pictures pic.twitter.com/3kzfEdro90 
— College Student (@ColIegeStudent) January 14, 2017 
All of those data overages have worked out in his favor. Rexford, who worked as a dishwasher before he started the account, ended up generating enough income to get himself through college by managing it. Everybody's attitude for next semester pic.twitter.com/617RzqZHbq 
— College Student (@ColIegeStudent) December 28, 2016 
Rexford, who isn’t currently a college student — he graduated from SVSU last year — used his tweeting experience to found an influencer marketing agency, Amp Social , a few months before graduation. 
“I had a lot of experience crafting content with millions of impressions for college students and millennials, and had already been working with companies through @ColIegeStudent to promote them,” he said. Related: 5 ways to go viral overnight (I did) 
Whether working with big brands like Jack in the Box or working with smaller startups, Rexford’s company is connecting them to millennials and generating creative content for them. 
“We’re getting an office in downtown Detroit this year, and for me that’s a really big thing,” he said. “I love Detroit and the comeback story, and I love working to be a part of that comeback story.” 
Even post-graduation, Rexford still has his hand in the account, and plans to keep it that way. Currently, several college students help to run the account to keep it fresh and updated. 
“Everyone can see themselves in the account. It is them. They can relate to it,” said Rexford. “It’s a day in the life of the average college student.” 
— College Student (@ColIegeStudent) January 23, 2017 Susannah Hutcheson is a Texas A&M student and a USA TODAY College digital producer.
